sen.j: 宇都宮 貞泰（うつのみや さだやす）とは、鎌倉時代・室町時代の武将。
sen.e: Sadayasu UTSUNOMIYA was a warlord during the Kamakura and Muromachi Periods.
Sadayasu UTSUNOMIYA was a warlord during the Kamakura and Muromachi Periods.
Sadayasu UTSUNOMIYA was a busho (Japanese military commander) during the Kamakura and Muromachi Periods.

sen.j: 三河守。
sen.e: Mikawa-no-kami (Provincial Governor of Mikawa)
Mikawa-no-kami (Provincial Governor of Mikawa)
Governor of Mikawa Province

sen.j: 当初は景泰、後に貞泰に。
sen.e: He was first called Kageyasu, then, this was changed to Sadayasu.
He was first called Kageyasu, and then his name was changed to Sadayasu.
He was first called Kageyasu, and then his name was changed to Sadayasu.

sen.j: 本姓は藤原氏。
sen.e: He was a member of the Fujiwara clan.
He was a member of the Fujiwara clan.
He was a member of the Fujiwara clan.

sen.j: 下野宇都宮氏第6代（藤原宗円から数えると第8代）の宇都宮貞綱の弟で九州の筑後国に下った宇都宮泰宗の子。
sen.e: Sadayasu was the son of Yasumune UTSUNOMIYA, the younger brother of Sadatsuna UTSUNOMIYA and the 6th head of the Shimotsuke-Utsunomiya clan (the 8th counting from FUJIWARA no Soen), who went to Chikugo Province in Kyushu.

Sadayasu was the son of Yasumune UTSUNOMIYA, the younger brother of Sadatsuna UTSUNOMIYA, and the 6th head of the Shimotsuke-Utsunomiya clan (the 8th counting from FUJIWARA no Soen), and went to Chikugo Province in Kyushu.

Sadayasu was the son of Yasumune UTSUNOMIYA, the younger brother of Sadatsuna UTSUNOMIYA, and the sixth head of the Shimotsuke-Utsunomiya clan (the eighth counting from FUJIWARA no Soen), and went to Chikugo Province in Kyushu.

sen.j: 武茂系図によれば、宇都宮景泰（後の貞泰）は、「京都烏丸に住み、その子の宇都宮宗泰については三河守で伊予住人」とある。
sen.e: According to the Mumo family records, "Kageyasu UTSUNOMIYA (later Sadayasu) lived at Karasuma, Kyoto. His son, Muneyasu UTSUNOMIYA was the Mikawa-no-kami and lived in Iyo."
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処ここの下りはいくつかの文章に分かれています。
sen.e: According to the Mumo family records, "Kageyasu UTSUNOMIYA (later Sadayasu) lived at Karasuma, Kyoto. His son, Muneyasu UTSUNOMIYA was the Mikawa-no-kami and lived in Iyo."
According to the Mumo family records, 'Kageyasu UTSUNOMIYA (later Sadayasu) lived at Karasuma, Kyoto. His son, Muneyasu UTSUNOMIYA was the Governor of Mikawa Province and lived in Iyo.'

sen.j: 伊予宇都宮系図には貞泰については「六郎、始景泰、美濃守、遠江守、野州宇都宮の住人、後京都に住す、法名蓮智」とある。
sen.e: The Iyo-Utsunomiya family record stated that "Sadayasu, who was called Rokuro and named Kageyasu at first, assumed the names Mino-no-kami and Totomi-no-kami. He lived at Utsunomiya, Yasu and moved to Kyoto later. His Buddhist name was Renchi."
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処ここの下りはいくつかの文章に分かれています。
sen.e: The Iyo-Utsunomiya family record states that "Sadayasu, who was called Rokuro and initially named Kageyasu, assumed the names Mino-no-kami and Totomi-no-kami. He lived at Utsunomiya, Yasu and later moved to Kyoto. His Buddhist name was Renchi."

The Iyo-Utsunomiya family record states that 'Sadayasu, who was called Rokuro and initially named Kageyasu, assumed the positions of the Governor of Mino Province and Governor of Totomi Province. He lived at Utsunomiya, Yasu and later moved to Kyoto. His Buddhist name was Renchi.'
sen.cmt: " "→' '美濃守、遠江守の訳、変更names→positionsご確認願います。

tit.e: Iyo Province Jito (medieval land steward in Japan)
Iyo Province Jito (medieval land steward in Japan)
Iyo Province Jito (medieval land steward in Japan)

sen.j: 1330年（元弘元年）に伊予国喜多郡の地頭となり、京都から伊予国喜多に移り、大洲の根来山城に拠る。
sen.e: In 1330, he became the land steward of Kita-gun, Iyo Province, moved from Kita-gun, Kyoto, and lived at Negororoyama Castle in Ozu.
In 1330, he became the land steward of Kita-gun, Iyo Province, moved from Kita-gun, Kyoto, and lived at Negororoyama Castle in Ozu.
In 1330, he became jito (manager and lord of manor) of Kita-gun, Iyo Province, moved from Kyoto to Kita, Iyo Province, Kyoto, and lived at Negoroyama-jo Castle in Ozu.
sen.cmt: 地頭の定訳from Kita-gun, Kyoto→from Kyoto to Kita, Iyo ProvinceNegororoyama→Negoroyama-jo

sen.j: 南北朝時代 (日本)当初は北朝方であり、四国の南朝方の得能通宗、忽那重清、土居通増らと戦う。
sen.e: During the Nanbokucho Period, he was the Northern Court and fought against Michimune TOKUNO, Shigekiyo KUTSUNA and Michimasu DOI of the Southern Court in Shikoku.
During the Nanbokucho Period, he was of the Northern Court and fought against Michimune TOKUNO, Shigekiyo KUTSUNA, and Michimasu DOI of the Southern Court in Shikoku.
During the period of the Northern and Southern Courts, he was of the Northern Court and fought against Michimune TOKUNO, Shigekiyo KUTSUNA, and Michimasu DOI of the Southern Court in Shikoku.

sen.j: 後醍醐天皇の第11皇子の懐良親王が征西大将軍に任命され、九州を目指して吉野を出立した。
sen.e: Emperor Godaigo's 11th son, Imperial Prince Kagenaga was appointed Seisei Taishogun (Generalissimo who oversaw the western Japan) and he left Yoshino for Kyushu.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Emperor Godaigo's 11th son, Imperial Prince Kagenaga, was appointed Seisei Taishogun (Generalissimo who oversaw western Japan) and he left Yoshino for Kyushu.
Emperor Godaigo's 11th son, Imperial Prince Kagenaga, was appointed seii taishogun (literally, "great general who subdues the barbarians") and he left Yoshino for Kyushu.
sen.cmt: 征夷大将軍の定訳「出立し、」→「出立した。」

sen.j: 瀬戸内海の海賊衆である熊野水軍の援助を得て伊予国忽那島（愛媛県松山市 - 旧北条市）へ渡った時、しばらく喜多の宇都宮貞泰の処に滞在。
sen.e: He received support from the Kumano Suigun Navy, a group of pirates in the Seto Inlet Sea, and after traveling to Katsuna-jima Island in Iyo Province (Matsuyama City, Ehime Prefecture, formerly Hojo City), he stayed at the residence of Sadayasu UTSUNOMIYA for a while.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: He received support from the Kumano Suigun Navy, a group of pirates in the Seto Inlet Sea, and after traveling to Katsuna-jima Island in Iyo Province (Matsuyama City, Ehime Prefecture, formerly Hojo City), he stayed at the residence of Sadayasu UTSUNOMIYA for a while.

He received support from the Kumano Suigun Navy, a group of pirates in the Seto Inland Sea, and after traveling to Katsuna-jima Island in Iyo Province (Matsuyama City, Ehime Prefecture, formerly Hojo City), he stayed at the residence of Sadayasu UTSUNOMIYA for a while.
sen.cmt: 瀬戸内海を用語集で多い訳に変更。

sen.j: ということは、当初は幕府方（北朝）の貞泰は、この頃は宮方（南朝 (日本)）に変わっていたことになる。
sen.e: That means Sadayasu, who was initially on the side of Bakufu (the Northern Court), was on the side of the Imperial Court (the Southern Court) by this time.
This means that Sadayasu, who was initially on the side of the Bakufu (the Northern Court), was on the side of the Imperial Court (the Southern Court) by this time.
This means that Sadayasu, who was initially on the side of the Bakufu (the Northern Court), was on the side of the Imperial Court (the Southern Court) by this time.

sen.j: 貞泰は、懐良親王と共に四国の伊予国喜多から九州の城井氏の豊前国仲津に移る。
sen.e: Sadayasu moved from Kita of Iyo Province in Shikoku to join the Ki clan in Nakatsu, Buzen Province together with Imperial Prince Kagenaga.
Sadayasu moved from Kita of Iyo Province in Shikoku to join the Ki clan in Nakatsu, Buzen Province together with Imperial Prince Kagenaga.
Sadayasu moved from Kita of Iyo Province in Shikoku to join the Kii clan in Nakatsu, Buzen Province together with Imperial Prince Kagenaga.

sen.j: 貞泰の子については、尊卑分脈、武茂系図、伊予宇都宮系図、筑後宇都宮系図、下野宇都宮系図その他においては、いくつかの異同がある。
sen.e: Regarding Sadayasu's children, there are different notations in the Sonpibunmyaku, Mumo family records, the Iyo-Utsunomiya family records, Chikugo-Utsunomiya family records and Shimotsuke-Utsunomiya family records.

Regarding Sadayasu's children, there are different notations in the Sonpibunmyaku, the Mumo family records, the Iyo-Utsunomiya family records, the Chikugo-Utsunomiya family records, and the Shimotsuke-Utsunomiya family records.

Regarding Sadayasu's children, there are different notations in the Sonpi Bunmyaku (a text compiled in the fourteenth century that records the lineages of the aristocracy), the Mumo family records, the Iyo-Utsunomiya family records, the Chikugo-Utsunomiya family records, and the Shimotsuke-Utsunomiya family records.

sen.j: それらをまとめれば、貞泰には、貞宗、義綱、貞久、貞邦、宗泰という子があり、伊予宇都宮系図は、伊予国守護となった貞宗を長子としているが、下野宇都宮系図その他では、豊前宇都宮氏に入嗣した義綱を長子としている。
sen.e: Summarizing these family records, Sadayasu had 5 sons, Sadamune, Yoshitsuna, Sadahisa, Sadakuni and Muneyasu, and the Iyo-Utsunomiya family records state that Sadamune, who as his eldest became the Shugo (Military Commissioner), while the Shimotsuke-Utsunomiya family records and others state that Yoshituna, who was adopted by the Buzen-Utsumoniya clan, was his eldest.

Summarizing these family records, Sadayasu had 5 sons, Sadamune, Yoshitsuna, Sadahisa, Sadakuni, and Muneyasu, and the Iyo-Utsunomiya family records state that Sadamune, who as his eldest became the Shugo (Military Commissioner), whereas the Shimotsuke-Utsunomiya family records and others state that Yoshituna, who was adopted by the Buzen-Utsumoniya clan, was his eldest.

Summarizing these family records, Sadayasu had five sons, Sadamune, Yoshitsuna, Sadahisa, Sadakuni, and Muneyasu, and the Iyo-Utsunomiya family records state that Sadamune, who as his eldest became the Governor of Iyo Province, whereas the Shimotsuke-Utsunomiya family records and others state that Yoshituna, who was adopted by the Buzen-Utsumoniya clan, was his eldest.
sen.cmt: 5→five「伊予国守護」の伊予国を追記して表記変更しました。

sen.j: これは、貞泰が伊予喜多にいた時と、豊前仲津に移った時の境遇を反映していると思われる。
sen.e: This reflects the circumstances of Sadayasu while he was in Iyo-kita and after moving to Nakatsu, Bizen.
This reflects the circumstances of Sadayasu while he was in Iyo-kita and after moving to Nakatsu, Bizen.
This reflects the circumstances of Sadayasu while he was in kita, Iyo and after moving to Nakatsu, Bizen.

sen.j: 伊予宇都宮系図が長男とする宇都宮貞宗は、伊予国守護となる。
sen.e: Sadamune UTSUNOMIYA, noted as the eldest in the Iyo-Utsunomiya family records, became the Shugo (Military Commissioner) of Iyo Province.
Sadamune UTSUNOMIYA, noted as the eldest in the Iyo-Utsunomiya family records, became the Shugo (Military Commissioner) of Iyo Province.
Sadamune UTSUNOMIYA, noted as the eldest in the Iyo-Utsunomiya family records, became the Governor of Iyo Province.

sen.j: 貞宗には子がおらず、伊予宇都宮氏の祖の宇都宮豊房（豊前宇都宮氏の宇都宮頼房の三男）が養子となる。
sen.e: Sadamune did not have any children and so he adopted Toyofusa UTSUNOMIYA (the third son of Yorifusa UTSUNOMIYA of Bizen-Utsunomiya clan), patriarch to the Iyo-Utsunomiya clan.
Sadamune did not have any children and so he adopted Toyofusa UTSUNOMIYA (the third son of Yorifusa UTSUNOMIYA of the Bizen-Utsunomiya clan), patriarch to the Iyo-Utsunomiya clan.
Sadamune did not have any children and so he adopted Toyofusa UTSUNOMIYA (the third son of Yorifusa UTSUNOMIYA of the Bizen-Utsunomiya clan), patriarch to the Iyo-Utsunomiya clan.

sen.j: 下野宇都宮系図が長男とする宇都宮義綱の子の宇都宮元綱は、北朝方の城井氏に入る。
sen.e: Mototsuna UTSUNOMIYA, the son of Mototsuna UTSUNOMIYA, who was noted as Sadayasu's eldest son in the Shimotsuke-Utsunomiya family records, joined the Shirai clan of the Northern Court.
Mototsuna UTSUNOMIYA, the son of Mototsuna UTSUNOMIYA, who was noted as Sadayasu's eldest son in the Shimotsuke-Utsunomiya family records, joined the Shirai clan of the Northern Court.
Mototsuna UTSUNOMIYA, the son of Yoshitsuna UTSUNOMIYA, who was noted as Sadayasu's eldest son in the Shimotsuke-Utsunomiya family records, joined the Kii clan of the Northern Court.

sen.j: 次男の南朝 (日本)方の宇都宮貞久の子の宇都宮懐久は、筑後宇都宮氏後裔の蒲池氏の祖となる。
sen.e: Kanehisa UTSUNOMIYA, the son of Sadahisa UTSUNOMIYA, Sadayasu's second son, of the Southern Court, became the patriarch of the Kamachi clan of Chikugo-Utsunomiya clan descendants.
Kanehisa UTSUNOMIYA, the son of Sadahisa UTSUNOMIYA, Sadayasu's second son, of the Southern Court, became the patriarch of the Kamachi clan of Chikugo-Utsunomiya clan descendants.
Kanehisa UTSUNOMIYA, the son of Sadahisa UTSUNOMIYA, Sadayasu's second son, of the Southern Court, became the patriarch of the Kamachi clan of Chikugo-Utsunomiya clan descendants.

sen.j: 三男の宇都宮貞邦は、兄貞久と共に懐良親王の九州の南朝方となり、甥の宇都宮懐久と共に筑後川の戦いで討ち死する。
sen.e: The third son, Sadakuni UTSUNOMIYA, became the Southern Court of Imperial Prince Kagenaga in Kyushu, joining his elder brother Sadahisa, and died fighting in the Battle of the Chikugo-gawa River with his nephew, Kanehisa UTSUNOMIYA.

The third son, Sadakuni UTSUNOMIYA, joined the Southern Court of Imperial Prince Kagenaga in Kyushu, joining his elder brother Sadahisa, and died fighting in the Battle of the Chikugo-gawa River with his nephew, Kanehisa UTSUNOMIYA.

The third son, Sadakuni UTSUNOMIYA, joined the Southern Court of Imperial Prince Kagenaga in Kyushu, joining his elder brother Sadahisa, and died fighting in the Battle of the Chikugo-gawa River with his nephew, Kanehisa UTSUNOMIYA.

sen.j: 四男の宇都宮宗泰は、長兄の貞宗の養子の宇都宮豊房（宇都宮冬綱の弟）の養子となり伊予宇都宮氏を継ぐ。
sen.e: His fourth son, Muneyasu UTSUNOMIYA, was adopted by his oldest brother's adopted son, Toyofusa UTSUNOMIYA (younger brother of Fuyutsuna UTSUNOMIYA) and became the head of the Iyo-Utsunomiya clan.
His fourth son, Muneyasu UTSUNOMIYA, was adopted by his oldest brother's adopted son, Toyofusa UTSUNOMIYA (younger brother of Fuyutsuna UTSUNOMIYA) and became the head of the Iyo-Utsunomiya clan.
His fourth son, Muneyasu UTSUNOMIYA, was adopted by his oldest brother's adopted son, Toyofusa UTSUNOMIYA (younger brother of Fuyutsuna UTSUNOMIYA) and became the head of the Iyo-Utsunomiya clan.
